summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16264 B; Qurʾānic Text: Q 18:47-18:55; 17 lines per page (orig. 19 lines); Dimensions: 265 x 322mm; Estimated date of production: 700-800 (?).
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museum in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 159f.):

"128. Inv. E. 16264 B. 3rd century A.H./9th century A. D. White, thin parchment. 32.2 x 26.5 cm. Written on both faces, seventeen lines to the page (the original number was probably nineteen), in brownish ink. Almost the full length and the full width are preserved but the upper side is badly damaged: the first six lines (as well as parts of lines 7-9) are entirely destroyed, and only the margins remain. The lower part is also damaged. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Kor. 18,47 (45) (و)ترى (beginning of line 6) – 49 (47) احد[ا] (traces of another line). Verso: 18,51 (49) متخذ (end of line 5) – 55 (53) يؤمنو[ا] (traces of two other lines). The script is reminiscent of nos. 10-13 in the Chicago Collection (see The Rise of the North Arabic Script, pp. 64-67 and Plates XVI-XIX), which Miss Abbott assigns to the second century A.H., and of no. 21 in the Vatican Library (see G. Levi Della Vida, Frammenti coranici, p. 16). As there, diacritical dots are expressed by strokes (heavier than in the older examples), vowel marks by red dots, a and u occasionally by the letters alif and wāw inscribed in red ink along with the corresponding dots (see The Rise, p. 39 and 65), hamza by a red semicircle, only on verso lines 9 (ورءا of 18,53) and 15 (يؤمنوا of 18,55). Small parallel strokes, three or four in number, are used as verse dividers: five-verse and ten-verse dividers do not appear in what has been left of this sheet."
